texts.text: options

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is the third post in a  series of posts on options trading . You can read this one out of order since it applies to almost everything you do in the stock market, including buying shares of stock.
texts.text: This is the third post in a  series of posts on options trading . You can read this one out of order since it applies to almost everything you do in the stock market, including buying shares of stock.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What is "max loss"
texts.text: What is "max loss"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The maximum loss on a trade is the worst outcome possible. Knowing this number helps you protect your account from huge losses and avoids terrible situations such as margin calls.  (This is when your broker is forced to arbitrarily sell off things in your account or demand money from you to get your account above a zero balance.)
texts.text: The maximum loss on a trade is the worst outcome possible. Knowing this number helps you protect your account from huge losses and avoids terrible situations such as margin calls.  (This is when your broker is forced to arbitrarily sell off things in your account or demand money from you to get your account above a zero balance.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When I first started learning about options trading, many people told me it was too dangerous. They told me "just buy shares since it's safer." If you begin analyzing maximum loss, you quickly realize that buying shares can be more risky than certain types of options.
texts.text: When I first started learning about options trading, many people told me it was too dangerous. They told me "just buy shares since it's safer." If you begin analyzing maximum loss, you quickly realize that buying shares can be more risky than certain types of options.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Maximum loss when buying shares
texts.text: Maximum loss when buying shares

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As an example, let's say you own 100 shares of Wal-Mart (WMT). It's trading around $148 today, so that means you have $14,800 in total equity. Your maximum loss would occur if the stock fell to zero and your total loss would be $14,800.
texts.text: As an example, let's say you own 100 shares of Wal-Mart (WMT). It's trading around $148 today, so that means you have $14,800 in total equity. Your maximum loss would occur if the stock fell to zero and your total loss would be $14,800.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A major retailer losing 100% of its value in a very short period of time is highly unlikely, but it's possible. There's nothing that prevents it from happening (other than the stock being halted in the market), and there is a chance that you could lose your entire investment.
texts.text: A major retailer losing 100% of its value in a very short period of time is highly unlikely, but it's possible. There's nothing that prevents it from happening (other than the stock being halted in the market), and there is a chance that you could lose your entire investment.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It took Enron about a year to drop to nearly zero, but some other drops have been much more abrupt. According to  Investopedia , some stocks have had some rough days:
texts.text: It took Enron about a year to drop to nearly zero, but some other drops have been much more abrupt. According to  Investopedia , some stocks have had some rough days:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Facebook lost $119B (2018-07-26)
texts.text: Facebook lost $119B (2018-07-26)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Intel lost $90B (2000-09-22)
texts.text: Intel lost $90B (2000-09-22)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Buying shares is a great way to start in investing for your future, but it's important to know your maximum amount of loss and ensure you're prepared to hold the stock through the down times.
texts.text: Buying shares is a great way to start in investing for your future, but it's important to know your maximum amount of loss and ensure you're prepared to hold the stock through the down times.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Maximum loss when buying options
texts.text: Maximum loss when buying options

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When you buy options, your maximum loss is the amount of premium you paid for the option. If you pay $200 for a call on a stock, your max loss is $200. The same goes for puts.
texts.text: When you buy options, your maximum loss is the amount of premium you paid for the option. If you pay $200 for a call on a stock, your max loss is $200. The same goes for puts.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The maximum loss scenario for bought options is when the option expires  out of the money . For a call, this means the stock price was under your strike price at the expiration time. For a put, the stock price would need to be above your strike price.
texts.text: The maximum loss scenario for bought options is when the option expires  out of the money . For a call, this means the stock price was under your strike price at the expiration time. For a put, the stock price would need to be above your strike price.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Maximum loss when selling a put
texts.text: Maximum loss when selling a put

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are two types of puts:
texts.text: There are two types of puts:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='cash secured puts'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='cash secured puts'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='naked puts'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='naked puts'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some of this was covered in the  The Dark Side: Selling Options  post, but it's worth talking about it here again. When you sell a put, you are obligated to purchase the stock at the strike price.
texts.text: Some of this was covered in the  The Dark Side: Selling Options  post, but it's worth talking about it here again. When you sell a put, you are obligated to purchase the stock at the strike price.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The max loss scenario here happens when the stock price falls to zero. Sure, that is unlikely, but it is possible. You will keep your premium from selling the put, however.
texts.text: The max loss scenario here happens when the stock price falls to zero. Sure, that is unlikely, but it is possible. You will keep your premium from selling the put, however.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: An important thing to remember is that your options are  capped . If you sell a put at a $100 strike price and collect $200 in premium, your losses are capped at $9,800. The stock can't go below zero (thankfully).
texts.text: An important thing to remember is that your options are  capped . If you sell a put at a $100 strike price and collect $200 in premium, your losses are capped at $9,800. The stock can't go below zero (thankfully).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With a cash secured put, you have cash on hand to deal with the loss and purchase the stock. However, with a naked put, you don't have cash to cover the loss. Your broker will issue a margin call and begin selling off other equities in your account to cover the loss. If that fails, they will demand that you deposit money to cover the loss.
texts.text: With a cash secured put, you have cash on hand to deal with the loss and purchase the stock. However, with a naked put, you don't have cash to cover the loss. Your broker will issue a margin call and begin selling off other equities in your account to cover the loss. If that fails, they will demand that you deposit money to cover the loss.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  Never sell naked puts. Ever. Seriously.
texts.text: 💣  Never sell naked puts. Ever. Seriously.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Maximum loss when selling a call
texts.text: Maximum loss when selling a call

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's where things can become horrifying. When you sell a call, there are two main types:
texts.text: Here's where things can become horrifying. When you sell a call, there are two main types:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='covered call'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='covered call'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='naked call'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='naked call'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's work with the covered call example first. Let's say you own 100 shares of XYZ and that stock is trading at $100 per share. You think the stock might go up a little but not a lot, so you sell a call at the $105 strike price.
texts.text: Let's work with the covered call example first. Let's say you own 100 shares of XYZ and that stock is trading at $100 per share. You think the stock might go up a little but not a lot, so you sell a call at the $105 strike price.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The best outcome would be for the stock to stay between $100-$105 so you don't lose money on the shares you own and your call is not exercised. There's no losses there.
texts.text: The best outcome would be for the stock to stay between $100-$105 so you don't lose money on the shares you own and your call is not exercised. There's no losses there.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What if the stock flew to $125? You get to keep the premium for selling your call option, but you have to sell those shares for $105 (since that was your strike price). Sure, you did lose $20 per share of profit ($2,000 total), but you still made money. You received the premium and your stock gained $5 per share ($500). You just missed out on some of the gains.
texts.text: What if the stock flew to $125? You get to keep the premium for selling your call option, but you have to sell those shares for $105 (since that was your strike price). Sure, you did lose $20 per share of profit ($2,000 total), but you still made money. You received the premium and your stock gained $5 per share ($500). You just missed out on some of the gains.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What if the stock falls to $50? You still keep your premium, but your $10,000 of equity (100 shares x $100) is now $5,000 of equity. You took a $5,000 loss. It's the same loss you would have had if you bought shares and didn't sell any options. However, you are getting the small benefit of the premium you received when you sold the call option.
texts.text: What if the stock falls to $50? You still keep your premium, but your $10,000 of equity (100 shares x $100) is now $5,000 of equity. You took a $5,000 loss. It's the same loss you would have had if you bought shares and didn't sell any options. However, you are getting the small benefit of the premium you received when you sold the call option.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In all of these scenarios, your losses are  capped . You know what you can possibly lose, but you know the limit of the loss.
texts.text: In all of these scenarios, your losses are  capped . You know what you can possibly lose, but you know the limit of the loss.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Never sell naked calls
texts.text: Never sell naked calls

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This loss is potentially so bad that it needs its own section.  Covered calls are nice because your collateral appreciates in value to cap your upside losses. What if you didn't own the stock?
texts.text: This loss is potentially so bad that it needs its own section.  Covered calls are nice because your collateral appreciates in value to cap your upside losses. What if you didn't own the stock?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's say you sold a call on XYZ for $105 again and it was trading at $100 per share. However, you don't own any shares this time.
texts.text: Let's say you sold a call on XYZ for $105 again and it was trading at $100 per share. However, you don't own any shares this time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the stock climbs to $104.99, your option expires out of the money and you keep your premium. Nice!
texts.text: If the stock climbs to $104.99, your option expires out of the money and you keep your premium. Nice!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the stock falls to $50, your option expires out of the money and you keep your premium. Nice!
texts.text: If the stock falls to $50, your option expires out of the money and you keep your premium. Nice!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the stock climbs to $125, you have a problem. You agreed to sell 100 shares to the buyer for $105 per share. You now have to buy 100 shares at $125 each (since that's the current stock price) and you have to sell them for $105 each. That's a $2,000 loss right there.
texts.text: If the stock climbs to $125, you have a problem. You agreed to sell 100 shares to the buyer for $105 per share. You now have to buy 100 shares at $125 each (since that's the current stock price) and you have to sell them for $105 each. That's a $2,000 loss right there.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, let's say that XYZ is a biotechnology firm and they report that they have a treatment for almost any cancer in the human body with a 14 day home treatment with almost no side effects. This is a life-altering change for people suffering from cancer. The stock climbs to $450 and investors say it will go higher. By the time the option expiration hits, the stock is worth $600.
texts.text: However, let's say that XYZ is a biotechnology firm and they report that they have a treatment for almost any cancer in the human body with a 14 day home treatment with almost no side effects. This is a life-altering change for people suffering from cancer. The stock climbs to $450 and investors say it will go higher. By the time the option expiration hits, the stock is worth $600.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What now? You sold a call option for $105. That means you have to buy 100 shares of the stock at its current price ($600 each) and sell that stock for $105 each. The math start to hurt:
texts.text: What now? You sold a call option for $105. That means you have to buy 100 shares of the stock at its current price ($600 each) and sell that stock for $105 each. The math start to hurt:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You purchase 100 shares at $600 each = $60,000.
texts.text: You purchase 100 shares at $600 each = $60,000.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You sell 100 shares at $105 each = $10,500.
texts.text: You sell 100 shares at $105 each = $10,500.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You lose $49,500. 🤯
texts.text: You lose $49,500. 🤯

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  Never sell naked calls. Ever. Seriously.
texts.text: 💣  Never sell naked calls. Ever. Seriously.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Know your max loss
texts.text: Know your max loss

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before you enter a trade, know what the worst case scenario will bring and ensure your account is prepared for it.
texts.text: Before you enter a trade, know what the worst case scenario will bring and ensure your account is prepared for it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I entered a trade earlier this year where I had a 85% percent chance of profit and the trade looked fantastic in my account. I had money to cover the loss but I doubted I would need it.
texts.text: I entered a trade earlier this year where I had a 85% percent chance of profit and the trade looked fantastic in my account. I had money to cover the loss but I doubted I would need it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The company suddenly dropped news within 48 hours of entering the trade. The news said that one of their acquisitions was a little slower and more expensive than they thought and their Q3 number would be revised down. The numbers were revised down a lot.  My nice gain turned into a $660 loss that I was forced to look at every day for a month until the expiration.  It was a daily reminder of two things:
texts.text: The company suddenly dropped news within 48 hours of entering the trade. The news said that one of their acquisitions was a little slower and more expensive than they thought and their Q3 number would be revised down. The numbers were revised down a lot.  My nice gain turned into a $660 loss that I was forced to look at every day for a month until the expiration.  It was a daily reminder of two things:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Anything can happen in the market.
texts.text: Anything can happen in the market.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: I was fully prepared for maximum loss.
texts.text: I was fully prepared for maximum loss.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
texts.text: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
